awd_titl_txt: MathScapes: Activating Public Spaces for Early Math Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematics plays a significant role in understanding and participating in science, technology, and engineering (STEM). Research shows that early mathematics experiences in everyday life are critical to the development of children's mathematical knowledge. This project will explore an innovative approach to fostering parent-child math interactions and conversations related to mathematical ideas. The approach will use community-based, exhibit installations called Mathscapes. These are artistic, culturally relevant, easily accessible, physical installations designed to encourage adults and children (ages 3 to 7) to use their immediate environment to playfully explore key early math concepts. The project also addresses a need for research about the cultural experiences and resources that marginalized children and families bring to mathematical conversations. Understanding parent-child interactions about mathematics community settings could result in new knowledge about early math learning among low income children and parents. As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. 

This exploratory study will design and investigate an innovative approach to encouraging math talk and math-related interactions between parents and children (ages 3-7) through the creation of MathScapes. These are temporary physical installations designed to use the immediate environment to playfully explore mathematical concepts. This study will be conducted in two Boston neighborhoods that are populated by low-income, non-dominant minority and immigrant families. Adopting a case study approach, the project will use observational methods, discourse analysis of parent/child talk, and interviews to study the interactions of 200 families at two neighborhood Mathscape installations. LENA devices will be used to capture parent/child talk at the Mathscapes while researchers use observational methods to document participant interactions, talk, and gestures. Data sources will include audio recordings of family talk, field notes of family interactions at Mathscape installations, surveys, and interviews. A qualitative approach will be used to produce research findings at multiple levels. The focus of the analysis will be to understand if this approach enhances the quality and quantity of math talk between parents and children.  The project will be carried out by a research-practice-community partnership in Boston, Massachusetts that includes community mathematics educators, education researchers, and participating children and families. The design of community installations could promote engagement with math through adult/child conversations in culturally-relevant contexts situated in the local environment. By addressing the cultural experiences and resources of young people, the project could greatly enhance our understanding of how to leverage the resources that children and families bring to engaging with mathematics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At the onset of this project we set out to learn more about how parents and caregivers engage with young children in dialogue around mathematical concepts in everyday environments, and how to best augment physical landscapes to increase the frequency of, and to expand and deepen these learning experiences. Our goals were to build on the positive learning interactions already taking place within families and communities to create 1) MathScapes ? artistic, culturally relevant, easily accessible, physical installations that would inspire, multiply and deepen adult-child early math interactions.

As described elsewhere, the project has been delayed by the pandemic, in several ways. First, obviously, we could not continue to meet with families on the Fletcher-Maynard playground to interact with the MathScapes installations.  

However, during the project, we did spend time working remotely on the data we had already collected.  Specifically, Professor Danny Martin and Professor Cathy O'Connor, began to examine the transcribed data records from the participants who had already completed the three-part interaction with the MathTalk team.  (Recall that in Part 1, adult participants first answered a questionnaire about their own experiences with math and how they interacted with their child about math and related topics in the home.  They were then interviewed by the subcontract PI, Dr. Nermeen Dashoush, about their answers.  In Part 2, they and their child met on the Fletcher-Maynard playground with Dr. Dashoush and two graduate assistants, and interacted with the installations there, at their own pace and according to what interested them.  Afterwards, we transcribed the recordings from the parent and child. In Part 3, the adult participants again filled out a questionnaire and again were interviewed by Dr. Dashoush about its contents.) 

Dr. Martin and Dr. O'Connor read through all of the transcribed interviews, and looked at the questionnaire results of the participants who had completed all three parts of the study.  As we did this we had three aims.  One was to compile a preliminary sense of the pragmatic issues, both positive and negative, that might be of use to the design team, as they continued to consider how to improve the MathScapes installations at a range of sites. Another aim was to get a preliminary sense of how to structure a broader quantitative analysis of the interactions.  We considered what elements of interactions are sufficiently robust to provide the substance of a quantitative analysis. A third aim was to select a smaller set of participant records that could allow us to do a deeper analysis of how family member identities and characteristics might play a role in how parents interact with their children at the MathScapes installations.

 We reported back to the MathScapes design team about several issues we observed from the records, including pragmatic issues such as the usefulness and accessibility of signage, the interpretability of the expected tasks (e.g. how am I supposed to use the abacus for my activity with the basketball hoop?), and how improvements in the structures (e.g. the abacus) had been taken up. We also observed the unexpected success of the installation centered around plants of different sizes.

Next, we observed that even without specific coding and counts, it is clear that in the majority of the interactions observed, the volume of utterances with mathematics as the focus is clearly higher than other kinds of questions or comments from parents to children. From these observations we can say that the MathScapes are good contexts that provide opportunities for rich math talk among caregivers and their children. 

An area of future development should include creating a code for each of the on-site transcripts.  This code can include both the topic/focus of the utterances parents produce, whether it is math-related or not, and what the topic/focus is specifically, in terms of the mathematical content and concepts that emerge.  In addition, one coding category can be devoted to the types of math-related questions: is it conceptual, procedural, declarative, factual, etc. 

 

Another area of future development can include how the caregiver-child interactions at the MathScapes is shaped by the parents' own orientations to parenting, their recollections of their own math learning, and their professional backgrounds. There is a lot to say here but the interviews reveal the parents have interesting things to say about their parenting styles and their math backgrounds (sometimes in relation to their own parents). This seems to shape how they interact with their children in the MathScapes. We also closely examined the two available cases involving families of color, and have been engaged in understanding how the parents' multiple identities (both mothers in this case) are evident in shaping their interactions with their children.

Addendum # 1

This project has focused on MathScapes: physical installations on playgrounds or other public areas that are artistic, culturally relevant, easily accessible, and that provide opportunities to reason mathematically and explore math concepts through playful interactions with the MathScapes.  We wanted to explore how these sites could more effectively inspire, multiply and deepen adult-child early math interactions, sometimes called "math talk."  Research shows that when parents and young children take time to explore, enjoy, and talk about math together, it sets the stage for positive early math experiences and helps young children view themselves as capable math learners.

But in reality, talking about math isn’t something that comes easily to everyone. In fact, 93% of adults in the U.S. report having at least some level of anxiety about math. So while every parent might want to ensure that their child’s earliest math learning experiences are positive, understandably, many simply don’t know where to begin. Thus overall, our work is focused on learning how best to support enjoyable and mathematically engaging talk around mathematical ideas as embodied in a variety of MathScapes.

At the onset of this project we set out to learn more about how parents and caregivers engage with young children in dialogue around mathematical concepts within MathScapes, and how to best augment them to increase the frequency of interactions, and to expand and deepen these learning experiences. Our intended focus was on families of color, particularly those from marginalized communities.  MathScapes installed at schools and in other sites within low-income communities may provide opportunities for learning and engagement with math concepts and activities. 

In this project, we had planned to focus on detailed analyses of recordings of parents and children interacting in MathScapes installations.  However, like many other projects across the country and the world, we ran into many obstacles during the Covid-19 pandemic.  

We began with a dozen recorded interviews with children and families at one MathScape installation based at a school.  Our project team began a preliminary analysis of the transcripts of these initial encounters, with several goals in mind. One was to compile a preliminary sense of the pragmatic issues, both positive and negative, that might be of use to the design team, as they continued to consider how to improve the MathScapes installations at a range of sites. Another aim was to get a preliminary sense of how to structure a broader quantitative analysis of the interactions. We considered what elements of interactions are sufficiently robust to provide the substance of a quantitative analysis. A third aim was to select a smaller set of participant records that could allow us to do a deeper analysis of how family member identities and characteristics might play a role in how parents interact with their children at the MathScapes installations. 

As the pandemic grew, we were unable to meet with families and children, but we were able to use some of the early results to support efforts of the design team to improve and clarify MathTalk installations.  Moreover, we were able to observe in the pre-pandemic interactions that the focus of the majority of parent-child talk was on mathematics in some form. This evidence that MathScapes are potentially productive contexts for rich math talk among caregivers and their children led to our next attempts to learn despite the pandemic. 

As the pandemic waxed and waned, we partnered with teachers and with local housing authorities to engage families. With local housing authorities we hosted play sessions at the housing developments.  Our work with teachers included professional development sessions about how to use MathScapes.  With teachers, our work focused on two things: identifying the "teacher learning goals" for working with students (see example below) and how to pose questions to embody those goals:

 

Practice Goal:

 

Indicator:

Example:

Utilizing various modalities

 

The educator will provide and utilize multiple modalities, such as visual aids, manipulatives, technology, and hands-on activities, to engage children in mathematics.

"Let's count how many bikes go by and jump to that number on the number line."

 

Many teachers have expressed the wish for more professional development and input on how to integrate the MathScapes experiences with their existing curriculum.  We are also working on that, including identifying the content goals for students, in the areas of numbers and counting, geometry and spatial relations, measurement and data, patterns and algebraic thinking.
